content: hello friends it's good to see you again
on today's episode of black magic crafts I'm going to try something a little bit
different one of the biggest challenges for me running this channel has always
been finding a way to put out quality tutorial videos nearly as often as I
would like to and as often as you guys would probably like to see the way in
which I film my videos and edit them takes a significant amount of time and
effort and that's not something that's very conducive to my current life so
that usually means that my episodes come out much farther apart than I would like
every three to four weeks so I've been trying to find a way that I can give you
guys more content without sacrificing that quality so this is what I've come
up with basically the idea is that I will continue to make the tutorial
videos like I always have and put them out every three to four weeks like I
always have but I'd like to give you guys X ODEs in between those maybe every
week or every two weeks and basically I have to find a way to do that that
requires less editing and possibly less builds on camera so whatever come up
with is the idea of picking certain projects that I'm working on or have
recently completed that are either too big or too complicated to condense into
a streamlined tutorial and either while I'm working on it or once I finished I
will just let the webcam roll and I will talk about it for 10 minutes 20 minutes
half an hour depends on the project I can give you guys an inside view of
different techniques let you know my thoughts on the different things I did
during the build what I would do differently that sort of thing for
example my styrofoam buildings people always ask me if I can make a tutorial
on that the reality is that those are big
projects they take a many many hours of work and they require a lot of different
techniques that I can't condense into a ten minute tutorial that is as clear and
concise as the ones I usually output are so this format is a way that I can still
show you guys some of those techniques and talk about those things so this is
the first attempt I'm going to need you guys to let me know if it's something
that you like or don't like keep in mind it will not replace my typical tutorials
this is additional content so if you like it let me know and more importantly
if you like it let me know what subjects you want me to do these on if there's
builds that you see me doing on the Blackmagic craft Facebook page and you
want to know something about one of those projects let me know in the
comments and I'll try to do one of these videos on that if there's a particular
technique or project that is small that doesn't require a full tutorial and you
just want to see my take on it let me know and I'll see if I can do one of
these videos that's basically the deal we're going into some uncharted
territory but I'm hopeful that this will allow me to give you guys more content
more often so let's zoom on into the table let's talk about these damn ruins
first we're going to start out here with the most recent project I've done which
is a set of a couple ruins something I've been needing for my game for quite
a while I never really got around to building them and in the last two weeks
I decided it was time to do it I made three different rooms and each one of
them I use slightly different techniques kind of getting a feel for what I liked
best and what turned out best and where the perfect ratio of effort and
product balance kind of lies and I think I found that each one of them is also
based differently using slightly different techniques so I'll talk about
that as well so the this one here is the first one that I built took a bit of a
look around when I made this one I went to my kind of default method of grabbing
some pink insulation foam and I first to use my props on table to mill a bunch of
pieces to a thickness that I wanted this is not a things that you can buy off the
shelf I actually made this out of inch and a half material so basically I cut a
bunch of strips this way out of inch and a half and then I turned it and I ran it
through the hot wire of table vertically and I made a bunch of these one
centimeter thick panels so when I did this one what did how I approached it
was four panels like this I traced out a 1 centimeter grid and the offset brick
same as I do my tiles cut without a knife run the pen through to give the
bevel and texture with 1012 and then once I had the brick pattern carved out
I knocked it in like every second one so that they would interlock so basically
on a piece like this this brick is part of this panel this brick is part of this
this is the you know so they actually interlock like that which I thought was
really cool I mean it locked in really made a very strong and
I was really happy with the way it turned out once I had the full panels
then I kind of just cut along and chopped out section like for example
this here is actually one piece that got cut out of this which was kind of nice
because it you know accurately represents the part of the wall that
fell in so I think that that method was really effective for creating something
that looked good had nice definition in the mortar lines and was strong that
being said I found it to be kind of an unpleasant and born in excruciating task
to do I find it really after both the first panel just like dungeon tiles it
gets tiresome to be doing the the grid work because it's a multi-stage thing

side for your measurement then cut on those lines then trace out again the
pattern this way marks guidelines then cut then do the whole thing over again
with pen and then once you finally feel like you're done
you have to flip it over and do the other side that's the one thing with
ruins compared to my other buildings my other buildings don't have interiors the

left with the floor so I only have to worry about decorating the outside with
the ruins you see the whole thing so essentially for me it's like twice as
much work as building a normal finished building so we are really tired of it
